title: MCl gravimetric analysis - particle diagram AgNO3

content.description:
The following questions refer to the below.

M+ is an unknown metal cation with a +1 charge. A student dissolves the chloride of the unknown metal, MCl, in enough water to make 100.0 mL of solution. The student then mixes the solution with excess AgNO3 solution, causing AgCl to precipitate. The student collects the precipitate by filtration, dries it, and records the data shown below. (The molar mass of AgCl is 143 g/mol.)

Mass of unknown chloride, MCl
 0.74 g

Mass of filter paper
 0.80 g

Mass of filter paper plus AgCl precipitate
 2.23 g
content.question:
Which of the following diagrams best represents the AgNO3 solution before the reaction occurs?

Note: water molecules are represented by the symbol
.

choices.label: Each figures shows multiple water molecules, a sphere labeled A g with a positive one charge, and a larger sphere labeled N O 3 with a negative one charge.  Option A. The sphere labeled A g with a positive one charge is in the top left-hand portion of the figure. Four water molecules are evenly spaced around it. The smaller spheres of the water molecules are pointed away from A g with a positive one charge.  The sphere labeled N O 3 with a negative one charge is in the bottom right-hand portion of the figure. Four water molecules are evenly spaced around it. The smaller spheres of the water molecules are pointed toward N O 3 with a negative one charge. There are 3 other water molecules in the figure.

Option B. The sphere labeled A g with a positive one charge is in the top left-hand portion of the figure. Four water molecules are evenly spaced around it. The smaller spheres of the water molecules on the above and below are pointed away from A g with a positive one charge and the smaller spheres of the water molecules on the left and right are pointed toward A g with a positive one charge.  The sphere labeled N O 3 with a negative one charge is in the bottom right-hand portion of the figure. Four water molecules are evenly spaced around it. The smaller spheres of the water molecules on the above and bellow are pointed toward N O 3 with a negative one charge and the smaller spheres of the water molecules on the left and right are pointed away from N O 3 with a negative one charge. There are 3 other water molecules in the figure.

Option C. The sphere labeled A g with a positive one charge is in the top left-hand portion of the figure. Four water molecules are evenly spaced around it. The smaller spheres of the water molecules are pointed away from A g with a positive one charge.  The sphere labeled N O 3 with a negative one charge is in the bottom right-hand portion of the figure. Four water molecules are evenly spaced around it. The smaller spheres of the water molecules are pointed away from N O 3 with a negative one charge. There are 3 other water molecules in the figure.

Option D. The sphere labeled A g with a positive one charge is touching the larger sphere labeled N O 3 with a negative one charge. There are 11 water molecules in the figure that are scattered around the two labeled spheres.

content.answer: Each figures shows multiple water molecules, a sphere labeled A g with a positive one charge, and a larger sphere labeled N O 3 with a negative one charge.  Option A. The sphere labeled A g with a positive one charge is in the top left-hand portion of the figure. Four water molecules are evenly spaced around it. The smaller spheres of the water molecules are pointed away from A g with a positive one charge.  The sphere labeled N O 3 with a negative one charge is in the bottom right-hand portion of the figure. Four water molecules are evenly spaced around it. The smaller spheres of the water molecules are pointed toward N O 3 with a negative one charge. There are 3 other water molecules in the figure.

skill.text: 3.C: Represent visually the relationship between the structures and interactions across multiple levels or scales (e.g., particulate to macroscopic).
